name: Feedback
description: Manual accessibility checklist for feedback components (alerts, toasts, progress indicators, spinners)

items.description: Status messages use appropriate ARIA live regions
items.procedure: Trigger status message and verify it uses role='status' or aria-live='polite'
items.expectedOutcome: Screen reader announces status message without moving focus

items.procedure: Trigger error and verify it uses role='alert' or aria-live='assertive'
items.expectedOutcome: Screen reader immediately announces error, interrupting current task

items.procedure: Verify alert has aria-labelledby or visible heading identifying the alert type
items.expectedOutcome: Screen reader announces alert type (error, warning, success, info)

items.description: Dismissable alerts can be closed with keyboard
items.procedure: Focus the dismiss button and press Enter or Space
items.expectedOutcome: Alert closes and focus moves appropriately

items.description: Toast auto-dismiss timing is adjustable or sufficient
items.procedure: Verify toast remains visible long enough to read (at least 5 seconds) or timing is adjustable
items.expectedOutcome: Users have sufficient time to read toast content

items.description: Alert type is not conveyed by color alone
items.procedure: Verify alerts use icons or text labels in addition to color to indicate type
items.expectedOutcome: Alert type is clear without relying on color perception

items.procedure: Verify progress bar/spinner has aria-label or aria-labelledby
items.expectedOutcome: Screen reader announces what is loading/processing

items.procedure: Verify progress bar has aria-valuenow, aria-valuemin, and aria-valuemax
items.expectedOutcome: Screen reader can announce progress percentage

items.procedure: Trigger loading state and verify completion is announced
items.expectedOutcome: Screen reader announces when loading completes or fails

items.description: Loading animations do not flash rapidly
items.procedure: Verify spinner/progress animations do not flash more than 3 times per second
items.expectedOutcome: No risk of triggering seizures from rapid flashing
